#!/bin/bash

# List of your dotfile packages (folders inside ~/dotfiles)
DOTFILES_DIR="$HOME/dotfiles"
PACKAGES=(
  nvim
  fish
  hypr
  waybar
  starship
  git
  ssh  # only if you include ~/.ssh/config (not keys!)
)

echo "üîß Starting dotfiles stow setup..."

cd "$DOTFILES_DIR" || { echo "‚ùå dotfiles directory not found!"; exit 1; }

for pkg in "${PACKAGES[@]}"; do
  echo -e "\nüì¶ Processing package: $pkg"

  # Do a dry run to find what will be linked
  while IFS= read -r line; do
    target="$HOME/$(echo "$line" | awk -F' -> ' '{print $2}')"

    # Backup if file/folder exists and is NOT a symlink
    if [ -e "$target" ] && [ ! -L "$target" ]; then
      echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  $target exists, backing it up to ${target}.bak"
      mv "$target" "${target}.bak"
    fi
  done < <(stow -nv "$pkg" 2>&1 | grep 'LINK:')

  # Actually stow it
  stow "$pkg"
done

echo -e "\n‚úÖ All done! Your configs are safely stowed."

ls .config/

I am writing to inform you about an issue I am facing while applying for an education loan through the PM Vidya Lakshmi Portal. I completed my intermediate (Class 12th) education from Raj Narain College, Hajipur Vaishali Bihar 844101, but currently, this college no longer offers intermediate courses and only admits students for bachelor's degree programs.

As a result, while filling out the application form, I am unable to find my intermediate college in the selection list under the institution dropdown. This is preventing me from proceeding with my education loan application.

I kindly request you to guide me on how to resolve this issue or suggest an alternative way to complete my application.

For your reference I've attached my 12th class certificate.
Amer Bidupur Bidupur Bazar Vaishali Bihar India 844503

Disk Scheduling Algorithms
Disk scheduling algorithms determine the order in which disk I/O requests are serviced. Efficient scheduling improves overall system performance by minimizing seek time, which is the time taken by the disk arm to move to the desired cylinder.

1. FCFS (First-Come, First-Served)
Requests are processed in the order they arrive.

Simple but can lead to long wait times if requests are scattered.

2. SSTF (Shortest Seek Time First)
Selects the request closest to the current head position.

Reduces total seek time but may cause starvation for distant requests.

3. SCAN (Elevator Algorithm)
Moves the head in one direction, servicing requests until the end, then reverses direction.

More efficient than FCFS and fairer than SSTF.

4. C-SCAN (Circular SCAN)
Moves the head in one direction, servicing requests, and jumps to the beginning without servicing on the return.

5. LOOK
Similar to SCAN, but the head only goes as far as the final request in each direction, not to the end.

6. C-LOOK
Similar to C-SCAN, but jumps back to the lowest request instead of the start of the disk.
write a note about disk scheduling algorithm, explain diffrent algorithms like fcfs, sstf, scan, cscan, lookl, and clook. write c code without comments for each algorithms simulation.

WITH
-- Step 1: Count total cases per district
cases_per_district AS (
    SELECT
        state_code,
        dist_code,
        COUNT(ddl_case_id) AS total_cases
    FROM cases_clean
    GROUP BY state_code, dist_code
),

-- Step 2: Count distinct judges per district
judges_per_district AS (
    SELECT
        j.state_code,
        j.dist_code,
        COUNT(DISTINCT j.ddl_judge_id) AS total_judges
    FROM judges_clean j
    GROUP BY j.state_code, j.dist_code
)

-- Step 3: Join and calculate judges per 10k cases
SELECT
    d.district_name,
    COALESCE(c.total_cases, 0) AS total_cases,
    COALESCE(j.total_judges, 0) AS total_judges,
    CASE
        WHEN COALESCE(c.total_cases, 0) = 0 THEN 0
        ELSE ROUND((j.total_judges::FLOAT / c.total_cases) * 10000, 2)
    END AS judges_per_10k_cases
FROM dist_key d
LEFT JOIN cases_per_district c
    ON d.state_code = c.state_code AND d.dist_code = c.dist_code
LEFT JOIN judges_per_district j
    ON d.state_code = j.state_code AND d.dist_code = j.dist_code
ORDER BY judges_per_10k_cases DESC;

The original eCourts platform does not provide information on the gender identity of judges and defendants. However, in the Indian context, gender and religious identity can often be inferred with reasonable accuracy from individuals‚Äô names. To leverage this, the research team at Devdatalab trained a machine learning classifier on a large, labeled database of names and applied it to assign these attributes within the legal dataset. For gender classification specifically, they used a dataset of 13.7 million names with labeled genders from the Delhi voter rolls.

Although gender was already preassigned in the dataset provided by Devdatalab, we developed a baseline logistic regression model using an independent open-source dataset of over 15,000 Indian names. This model achieved a satisfactory performance, with an accuracy of 86%.

The original data source eCourts platform does not provide gender identity on judges and defendants. However, gender and religious identity can be determined quite accurately in India based on individuals‚Äô names. The research team at Devdatalab trained a machine classifier on a large database of labeled names and then used it to assign these characteristics in the legal data. To classify gender, we use a dataset of 13.7 million names with labeled gender from the Delhi voter rolls.

Even though gender were preassigned in the dataset provided by the Devdatalab, we trained a baseline Logistic regression model on 15,000+ indian names from an open source dataset, The model performance was quite satisfactory with 86% accuracy.

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Sample: reading your uploaded data from a file if it were CSV or TXT
# Since I have the extracted data, let's simulate it as a dictionary
data = {
    'district_name': ['BENGALURU', 'Mumbai CMM Courts', 'Nagpur', 'Indore', 'Vadodara',
                      'Lakshadweep', 'Ri Bhoi', 'West Jaintia Hills', 'Dima Hasao', 'Kargil'],
    'filed_cases': [1612911, 935631, 625566, 576653, 385326, 248, 99, 589, 888, 676]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Sorting for top 5 and bottom 5
top5 = df.sort_values(by='filed_cases', ascending=False).head(5)
bottom5 = df.sort_values(by='filed_cases', ascending=True).head(5)

# Plotting
plt.figure(figsize=(14, 8))
sns.set_style("whitegrid")

# Top 5
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
sns.barplot(x='filed_cases', y='district_name', data=top5, palette='viridis')
plt.title('Top 5 Districts by Filed Cases')
plt.xlabel('Filed Cases')
plt.ylabel('')
for index, value in enumerate(top5['filed_cases']):
    plt.text(value + 5000, index, f'{value}', va='center')

# Bottom 5
plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
sns.barplot(x='filed_cases', y='district_name', data=bottom5, palette='magma')
plt.title('Bottom 5 Districts by Filed Cases')
plt.xlabel('Filed Cases')
plt.ylabel('')
for index, value in enumerate(bottom5['filed_cases']):
    plt.text(value + 10, index, f'{value}', va='center')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

SELECT
  dk.district_name,
  COUNT(*) AS filed_cases
FROM cases_clean cc
JOIN dist_key dk ON cc.state_code = dk.state_code AND cc.dist_code = dk.dist_code AND cc.year = dk.year
GROUP BY  dk.district_name;

SELECT
  dk.district_name,
  COUNT(*) AS pending_cases
FROM cases_clean cc
JOIN dist_key dk ON cc.state_code = dk.state_code AND cc.dist_code = dk.dist_code AND cc.year = dk.year
WHERE cc.date_of_decision IS NULL
GROUP BY  dk.district_name;
